t: In*pn my bed at night I*ln sought the one I love; I*ln sought him, but did not find him.
I*ln will arise now and go about the city, through*ln the streets and the plazas. I*ln will seek the one I love. I*ln sought him, but did not find him.
The*ln guards who go about the city found me. I*ln asked them, “Have you seen the one I love?”
I*ln had just passed them when*ln I found the one I love. I*ln held on to him and would not let him go until*ln I brought him to my mother’s house— to*ln the chamber of the one who conceived me.
Young*ln women of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ln the gazelles and the wild does of the field, do*ln not stir up or awaken love until*ln the appropriate time.
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness like*ln columns of smoke, scented*ln with myrrh and frankincense from*ln every fragrant powder of the merchant?
Look!*pn Solomon’s bed surrounded*ln by sixty warriors from*ln the mighty men of Israel.
All*ln of them are skilled with swords and*ln trained in warfare. Each*ln has his sword at his side to*ln guard against the terror of the night.
King*pn Solomon made a carriage for himself with*ln wood from Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, its*ln back of gold, and*ln its seat of purple. Its*ln interior is inlaid with love by*ln the young women of Jerusalem.
Go*ln out, young women of Zion, and*ln gaze at King Solomon, wearing*ln the crown his mother placed on him on*ln the day of his wedding— the*ln day of his heart’s rejoicing.
